content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Naive solution is simple, avoiding timeouts is harder, which is fine. I like the idea, good job!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: simple solution does'nt work (that's good thing for a medium level).
Merge sort seems to work.
The contribution seems to be originale with a sort algorithm discovery.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I solved it in PHP, now all tests pass with < 1 sec runtime and below memory limit. All generated stubs seem valid.

I also tried to solve this with Merge Sort. Good news: I don't run out of memory this time. Bad news: the solution timeouts at test 9 and validator 9. This is a quite standard "theta(n log n)" code with recursion. And no, I don't pass arrays as arguments, only array indexes.

I tried to solved this with a Binary Indexed Tree and avoiding any recursion, but ran out of space at test 9 and Validator 9. 
Unfortunately the BIT based solution requires an extra array of size 'max number to be sorted'.
So maybe only a MergeSort based solution is viable, with space requirement proportional to N.

Not much feedback on this one, but it seems ready enough imo for the approval process.
Please share your thoughts !

Changed the puzzle from swap sort to inversion count.
Reduced the maximum value of N to prevent timeouts in some other languages.
Also changed difficulty to medium.
I set the difficulty to hard because of the performance requirements for the last tests. Feedback appreciated.

Seems to me the real blocker is likely going to be RAM.

As-compact-as-possible 10^8 values represented as packed 32-bit ints is already more than half of the allowed RAM.
A lot of languages need some form of boxing around them to do anything interesting, assuming they even provide easy access to 32-bit ints when the machine word is 64.

What's the puzzle's goal? In-place merging, or inversion count?

Can you time test 9 locally to have an idea of the run time ?
I have a solution in C# and JS, they both pass the last test on CG in~1.5sec. That's getting close to the limit admittedly, but since JS is a rather slow language, I figured it should be ok for everyone.
I'll reduce the max constraint if that doesn't work out.

Here is my local log for Test 8 and 9:
It is in PHP, without JIT compiler.

========
TEST 08
N =          1,000,000

Algorithm:   MERGESORT
Time used:   3.1443 sec
Memory used: 94,371,840 bytes

Algorithm:   BIT
Time used:   2.1789 sec
Memory used: 174,063,616 bytes

========
TEST 09
N =          3,000,000

Algorithm:   MERGESORT
Time used:   10.3508 sec
Memory used: 346,030,080 bytes

Algorithm:   BIT
Time used:   7.9366 sec
Memory used: 677,380,096 bytes

I know little about PHP but imo there's something wrong. Your results can't be that bad compared to JS, we're talking 10x slower here.

For reference when running test 9 locally with dotnet I get the following results:
Inversions: 2250109156294
Time used: 906ms
Memory used: 78 098 432 bytes

Edit:
Running test 9 locally with node.js :
Inversions: 2250109156294
Time used: 893ms
Memory used: 113 843 792 bytes

As far as I know, JS has a JIT compiler.
If I turn on JIT for my local PHP, it speeds up my code 3x faster, so test 9 would be 3.5 sec. But JIT for PHP is not available on CG which runs a 2 year old PHP release.
3.5sec is still much more than 893ms.
Maybe my code is not the most optimized, but it is "n log n".
Note that PHP has no true 'vector' type, its 'array' implementation is actually an ordered hashmap which is  dynamically resized automatically by the power of 2 as needed. So not the fastest kid on the block.

Yes JS is compiled to bytecode with a JIT compiler, but it also doesn't have a true vector type. Arrays are custom hashmaps optimized for sequential indexing.
I'll give PHP a try locally, I'm curious about this performance discrepancy.

Edit : getting the same performance as your tests, I'm really shocked tbh :o Although my memory consumption is more reasonable.
Inversions: 2250109156294
Time used: 9.81s
Memory used: 96 869 216 bytes

Not sure what to do, should I remove the latest tests to give php a chance ?

Yes, puzzle shall be solvable in all languages. And solo  puzzles shall not  be about micro-optimization, so a Θ(n log n) code shall pass, even if it is not the best code ever. 
What is important imho, is to rule out the naive Θ(n^2) solutions, but n = 10^6 is enough for that.
 It's up to you what to do. If you decide to limit the constraints, please update them also in the statement. 
Otherwise, it is a good puzzle, statement is clear, so I am ready to approve it if I will be able to pass it. (Did not check the 27 language stubs though...)

Fair enough, I've capped N at 3x10^5 and updated the constraints.
My JS solution transcribed to PHP can pass the last test in time so it should be alright now.

That would be in-place merging, inversion count only gives a lower bound on the required amount of steps.

I'll reduce the maximum value of N if needed, I thought about the RAM limit but didn't take boxing into account. That said, 10^8 * 4 is less than 50MB of RAM, I seem to remember that the limit was more than 10x that (or maybe that was limited to some modes like multiplayer, not sure).

Edit : actually I was off by a power of 10, I reduced the max to 5x10^6.

I count 10^8 packed int32s to take 381.5MiB, with the CG limit at 768.

FWIW, in the past I've tried to write puzzles that would force e.g. online algorithms, but never found a way to make it approachable by all classes of languages. (so for now they're unpublished). The platform doesn't seem to be a good fit for those.

(until proven otherwise)

Yes you're right, for some reason I was picturing 10^8 as 10^7 in my head.
I've set the new maximum value of N to 5x10^6, it's challenging enough in performance and should stay well below the RAM limit.
Thanks for confirming 768 btw, that's useful info.
Next time you need it: it's in the FAQ ;)

Given the non-existent feedback, I changed it to inversion count.
Hopefully people like it better this way :o
